Shalini Padmanabhan is Director of Research Programs at The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. At the Foundation, she leads the biology team focusing on identifying, characterizing and validating targets and pathways responsible for the development and progression of Parkinson's disease. Shalini earned an undergraduate degree in Pharmaceutical Sciences from U.I.C.T, India and a PhD in Neuroscience from the Medical College of Georgia. Prior to joining the Foundation, Shalini trained as a postdoctoral research scientist at Columbia University where she worked on validating novel targets to treat Parkinson’s disease using a gene therapy approach.

biography.iv: Ekemini is the Managing Director for the Aligning Science Across Parkinson's (ASAP) initiative. Ekemini led the development and launch of ASAP and, in her role, she leads its programmatic and operational management. Ekemini is a trained molecular biologist who earned her BA from the Johns Hopkins University and PhD from the University of Maryland School of Medicine. Previously, she was a director at the Milken Institute Center for Strategic Philanthropy where she helped to shape and co-direct the center’s medical research practice. There she designed and facilitated several multi-sector think tank sessions and crafted research programs for philanthropic support.

iv.question: How good is the evidence that Lewy body spread rather than autonomous expression in different regions of the brain responsible for neurodegeneration?
How good is the evidence that Lewy bodies are a primary cause of rather than a reflection of pathology?

If Lewy body spread is a real source of pathology, how is transmission between cells mediated:  a-syn fibers, soluble a-syn, or a-syn within extracellular vesicles?  How is internalized a-syn exposed to and assembled with endogenous a-syn and then secreted from cells?

To what extent are the pathologies associated with genetic forms of PD, such as synuclein aggregation and spread, delayed traffic and buildup of material designated for the lysosome, a defect in ciliary biogenesis, failure of mitophagic turnover of damaged mitochondria, recapitulated in non-genetic forms of the disease?

biography.iv: Randy is a Professor in the Department of Molecular and Cell Biology, University of California, Berkeley, and an Investigator of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute.  He studied the enzymology of DNA replication as a graduate student with Arthur Kornberg at Stanford University.  His current interest in cellular membranes developed during a postdoctoral period with S. J. Singer at the UC Diego.  Schekman’s laboratory investigates the mechanism of vesicular traffic in the secretory pathway in eukaryotic cells Among his awards are the Gairdner International Award, the Albert Lasker Award in Basic Medical Research and the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, which he shared with James Rothman and Thomas Südhof.  He served as Editor-in-Chief of the PNAS and was the founding editor of eLife.

responsibilities.iv: Alejandro will co-supervise the data cleaning and preparation as part of the GP-2 cohort integration project. He will use SNP based heritability to determine the genetic heritability of core Parkinson's phenotype measures. He will examine baseline clinical phenotypes. Also, he will consider intermediary phenotypes that might explain Parkinson's progression, and he will use genome wide association and survival approaches to gain new insights into the biology of PD.

researchInterests.iv: Alejandro is interested in harmonizing and performing GWAS over longitudinal data in order to know more about the genetic architecture of PD

biography.iv: Sonia García Ruiz is a PhD student and software developer at  UCL Great Ormond Street Institute of Child Health. She completed her Bachelor’s in Computer Science at the University of Miguel Hernández (Spain) in 2014. After that, she accumulated 2 years of experience as a software and web developer, working with clients such as Microsoft and Deloitte. In 2017 she completed her master’s degree in Artificial Intelligence at the University of Murcia in 2018. In the Ryten lab, she is focused on finding the mechanisms underlying the alternative splicing in human cells, and how those different products may interfere in human health. Additionally, she uses her knowledge of web development to help build analysis and visualisation tools for easier data interpretation.

biography.iv:
Kelsey C. Martin is the Dean for the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA. She received her undergraduate degree in English and American Language and Literature at Harvard University. After serving as a Peace Corps volunteer in the Democratic Republic of Congo, she entered the MD-PhD program at Yale University where she studied influenza virus-host cell interactions in the laboratory of Dr. Ari Helenius, receiving her PhD degree in Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry and her MD degree in 1992. She did her postdoctoral training in neurobiology with Nobel Laureate Eric Kandel at Columbia University, and joined the UCLA faculty in 1999. The Martin lab integrates molecular cell biological, electrophysiological and next‐generation genomic approaches to understand how experience changes brain connectivity to store long‐term memories.

Martin’s research program provides insight not only into learning and memory in the healthy brain, but also into cognitive disorders that accompany neuropsychiatric disorders, including autism, anxiety disorders and Alzheimer’s disease. Outside of UCLA, Martin is a Senior Fellow at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute Janelia Research Campus. She is on the editorial board of Cell, the board of directors for the Burroughs Wellcome Fund and the board of directors for the McKnight Endowment Fund for Neuroscience. In 2016, she became a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of the National Academy of Medicine.

responsibilities.iv: Laura will be responsible for using cell models to investigate how different GBA1 mutations influence alpha-synuclein pathology. biography.iv: Andrew is an NIH Distinguished Investigator within the Intramural Research Program of the National Institute on Aging. Andrew works on the genetic basis of neurological disorders including Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer’s disease, dystonia, ataxia, dementia with Lewy bodies, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Andrew has received the Annemarie Opprecht Award for Parkinson’s disease research, the Jay van Andel Award for Outstanding Achievement in Parkinson’s Disease Research, the American Academy of Neurology Movement Disorders Award, the Robert A Pritzker Prize for Leadership in Parkinson’s Disease, and an Honorary Doctorate from the University of Sunderland.

biography.iv:
Chandra’s research efforts have concentrated on elucidating the cellular, molecular, and genetic players leading to murine lupus nephritis, with corresponding translational studies in human lupus nephritis. Dr. Mohan’s ongoing studies are aimed at tapping leads from proteomic platforms to mine new biomarkers and targets in chronic rheumatic diseases and selected cancers, and to apply the latest bioengineering technologies to advance the management of these ailments.
He currently holds the Cullen Distinguished Professorship at the University of Houston, in Houston, TX. Dr. Mohan is an elected member of the American Society of Clinical Investigation and the Henry Kunkel Society. He has published ~250 articles, largely in the area of autoimmunity and biomarkers.

As a trainee, she studied the immune and regenerative responses following targeted glia apoptosis, as well as assessed the complex relationships between how the immune and nervous systems interact to drive repair and promote recovery. She was supervised by leaders in the field of Multiple Sclerosis research, including Trevor Kilpatrick and Tobias Merson at the University of Melbourne during her PhD, as well as Jeff Biernaskie and Rajiv Midha at the University of Calgary during her postdoc. Amongst her successes, she was awarded Postdoc of the Year at her institution, and also finds joy in mentoring the next generation of scientists.

biography.iv: Helene is a Professor at UCL Queen Square Institute of Neurology. During her PhD at INSERM in Angers (1999-2002), France, she studied the cell signaling of the cytokines of the Interleukin-6 family. She then undertook a postdoctoral training with Professor Julian Downward at Cancer Research UK, London Research Institute (2002-2007). The discoveries and work she undertook in the mitochondria and cancer area led her towards neurodegeneration and in 2007, she successfully applied for an MRC Career Development Fellowship to work at UCL Queen Square Institute of Neurology. She has been working on mitochondrial dysfunction un neurodgeneration ever since, In 2013, she accepted a Senior Lecturer position at the UCL Queen Square Institute of Neurology and was appointed as Professor in 2019.

biography.iv: Frances Platt is an expert on glycosphingolipids (GSL) and glycosphingolipid (GSL) lysosomal storage disorders. She pioneered the first pharmacological approach to treat these disorders that she termed substrate reduction therapy (SRT). This led to the development of an approved drug (miglustat) for type 1 Gaucher disease. Miglustat was approved by the EMEA in 2002 and by the FDA in 2003 and is now in use worldwide as the first oral therapy for a lysosomal disorder. Miglustat was also approved (2009) for Niemann-Pick disease type C1 (NPC) and is the first disease-modifying therapy for this severe progressive neurodegenerative lysosomal disorder.

biography.iv: Judith Frydman is the Donald Kennedy Chair in Humanities and Sciences and a Professor in the Departments of Biology and Genetics at Stanford University. She received her PhD in Biochemistry from the University of Buenos Aires, Argentina and received postdoctoral training in Ulrich Hartl’s lab. Her lab is focused on understanding how the network of molecular chaperones and the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway maintain proteostasis in eukaryotic cells and how its disfunction leads to disease and aging. Her lab also harnesses these insights to develop therapeutic approaches to ameliorate human diseases including neurodegenerative diseases and to identify specific interventions that disfavor the production of toxic protein species.

biography.iv: Dr. Ruben Fernandez-Busnadiego received his undergraduate degree in Physics from the Complutense University of Madrid.  He carried out his PhD at the Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry, investigating synaptic structure by cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET). Later on, as a postdoctoral fellow at the Yale School of Medicine, he studied various aspects of membrane biology in neurons. He then returned to the Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry to lead a group investigating the structural links between protein aggregation and cell death in neurodegenerative diseases. Since 2019, he is a Professor at the University Medical Center Göttingen. His group continues to employ cutting edge cryo-ET to investigate in situ the structural basis of cellular function and disease-related dysfunction.

researchInterests.iv: Michel uses a molecular cell biology approach to study how cellular pathways involved in innate and adaptive immunity contribute to the pathological process leading to Parkinson's disease.

responsibilities.iv: Michel will be responsible for the work done at the cell level in antigen presenting cells to decipher the role of PD-related proteins in the engagement of an innate immune response during stress and how these proteins actively link the transition to an adaptive, autoimmune, response. The work of his group will help to build a detailed “Cell Map” indicating where and how multiple PD proteins act along a common pathway that, when altered, leads to potentially deleterious autoimmune mechanisms.

biography.iv: Mina is Professor of Clinical Genetics at the UCL Great Ormond Street Institute of Child Health and is an Honorary Consultant in Clinical Genetics at Great Ormond Street Hospital. She studied medicine at Cambridge University and then moved to University College London to obtain an MD-PhD. Under the supervision of Professor Geoffrey Burnstock, she studied purinergic signalling in skeletal muscle. She went on to complete a postdoctoral fellowship in biomedical informatics with Professor John Hardy on eQTL analysis in human brain. She currently splits her time between her lab, which focuses on brain transcriptomics, and her clinical practice.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Mina has experience in the analysis of transcriptomic data generated from post-mortem human brain and its integration with genomic data.

researchInterests.iv: Mina is interested in using brain transcriptomics to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying rare and complex forms of neurological diseases.

responsibilities.iv: Mina is responsible for the analysis of transcriptomic data generated from post-mortem human brain samples, as well as that generated on mouse models of PD progression. This will involve the application of analytic pipelines for single nucleus and bulk RNA-sequencing. Using this form of data, Mina hopes to identify transcriptomic signatures of PD progression, which can provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying this process.

researchInterests.iv: Beatrice is interested in modeling Parkinson’s disease using induced pluripotent stem cells and identify rapid and early disease relevant phenotypes.

responsibilities.iv: Beatrice will perform single nucleus RNAseq together with her colleague Zhixiang  on 100 frozen midbrain and 100 cortex samples from human postmortem brains and generate cDNA libraries for sequencing. Beatrice will also perform quality-controls (e.g. qPCR) for the snRNAseq work. Moreover, she will confirm cell type-specific expression of eGenes in human brains using RNA in situ hybridization.

biography.iv: Jeffrey H. Kordower is the Jean Schweppe-Armour Professor of Neurological Sciences, Professor of Neurosurgery, Director, Research Center for Brain Repair, Section Head of Neuroscience, and Director of the Neuroscience Graduate Program at Rush University Medical Center. Jeff is an international authority in movement disorders, with special expertise in experimental therapeutic strategies in Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and Huntington’s disease using nonhuman primate models.  Jeff has published over 350 papers, has lectured all over the world, has been on over 20 Editorial boards, and is on the SAB’s of many biotech companies.

researchInterests.iv: Jeff's major research interests are understanding the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s disease and using that information to create valid animal models, especially nonhuman primate models, and use these models to test novel experimental therapeutics.

responsibilities.iv: Jeff is the Principal Investigator of this program. He is currently an endowed Professor in the Department of Neurological Science and Section Head of Neurobiology at Rush University Medical Center. He has co-designed the program and will be responsible for all non-human primate surgeries, histology, analysis and writing of manuscripts.

biography.iv: Kallol’s PhD was from Indian Institute of Science, where his goal was to uncover the molecular diversity present in the venoms of marine cone snails and understand how it impairs the functions of key ion channels and transporters. Kallol’s post-doctoral work, in Carol Robinson’s lab (Oxford university), led to a transformative advancement that enabled top-down mass spectrometric (MS) analysis of membrane protein-lipid complexes. During this period, he was a Fellow of 1851 Royal Commission, UK. Subsequently, he ‘crossed the pond’ and started his lab at Yale School of Medicine in Fall’2018. Combining MS with orthogonal approaches, Kallol’s lab is focused on developing platforms that enable quantitative analysis of macromolecular protein-lipid complexes directly from the cellular environment.

Huw is Professor of Clinical Neuroscience at UCL Institute of Neurology, and Honorary Consultant Neurologist at the Royal Free Hospital and the National Hospital, Queen Square.  He was  Professor in Neurology and Neurogenetics at Cardiff University from 2003-2013. 
His clinical and research training took place at the National Hospital Queen Square, the Mayo Clinic and the Western Pacific island of Guam.  
His main interests are Neurogenetics, Movement Disorders and Dementia.  He is leading a UK-wide research network in PSP and Cortico-basal degeneration (PROSPECT), a UK-wide research project in genetic Parkinson’s (Parkinson’s families project).    He also studies genetic determinants of progression and variation in Parkinsonian disorders to define new treatments.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Huw is a neurologist and geneticist who has worked in neurogenetics from 1997.  He has experience in new Mendelian gene discovery, and the analysis of genome wide analysis, looking at the impact of common variants on risk and phenotype in neurological disease.

researchInterests.iv: Huw works on the genetics of progression and phenotype in neurodegenerative disorders

biography.iv: Lilia is an experienced researcher with excellent understanding of basic neurobiology of neurodegenerative diseases and mechanisms of neurodegeneration. She worked on the prion hypothesis in Alzheimer's disease (studying tau protein) and in Parkinson's disease (studying alpha synuclein) and have an in-depth understanding on the common pathological mechanisms in these two diseases.

researchInterests.iv: Lilia is interested in the role of intestinal infections in the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s disease.

responsibilities.iv: Lilia will support the research and administrative activities of the Desjardins team by assisting with the day-to-day research operations, routinely monitoring and communicating project progress, addressing project issues and managing the budget. She will also organize and moderate team meetings and follow up on action items to ensure the team is on track with milestones. Additionally, Lilia will serve as primary contact with funding bodies and collaborators.

biography.iv: Claudia is Lecturer in Translational Neuroscience at the School of Pharmacy, University College London (UCL, UK). She has a degree in Pharmaceutical Biotechnology and during her PhD she studied the process of amyloid deposition in Alzheimer's disease at the Mario Negri Institute for Pharmacological Research in Milan (Italy). After her PhD she joined UCL and the University of Reading; during her PostDoc she trained in bioinformatics and genetics of neurodegenerations.

biography.iv: Dr. Harper is the Chair of the Department of Cell Biology at Harvard Medical School. His work focuses on the functions, mechanisms and targets of cullin-RING ubiquitin ligases. His recent work has led to the discovery of a phosphorylation-driven feed-forward ubiquitylation pathway controlling PARKIN-dependent mitophagy, and a molecular understanding of the pathways controlling selective autophagy. Dr. Harper has employed interaction proteomics to define interactions and complexes for more than 10,000 human proteins, providing numerous complexes linked to biological pathways. Awards include the Javits Neuroscience award, and election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

biography.iv: Monica is a Research Assistant in the Proukakis lab, Department of Clinical and Movement Neurosciences, University College London. She graduated with High Distinction from the University of Toronto, Canada, with a Neuroscience Specialist degree. She then completed her MRes in Experimental Neuroscience at Imperial College London with Distinction. At Imperial, she conducted a multi-omics study of open-source GWAS, transcriptomics, proteomics and lipidomics data to map the metabolic consequences of Alzheimers Disease.

researchInterests.iv: Monica is investigating the presence of somatic DNA copy number variants (CNVs) in synucleinopathies, their region and cell-type distribution in post-mortem brain tissue.

biography.iv: Thierry is Professor in the Department of Human Genetics, University of Leuven (KU Leuven, Belgium). He studied Bioscience Engineering: Cell and Gene Biotechnology, and holds an inter-university post-graduate in Human Genetics. Following his PhD at KU Leuven, he pioneered single-cell microarray analyses, and in 2010, he joined the Cancer Genome Project at the Wellcome Sanger Institute (Sanger, UK) to explore next-generation sequencing technologies for single-cell genomics. Since 2011, he has been an associate faculty member at Sanger, and a founding member of the Sanger-EBI Single-Cell Genomics Centre. In 2014, he became Associate Professor at KU Leuven following a five-year tenure track, and was appointed Full Professor in 2017.

biography.iv: Warren leads movement disorders preclinical research efforts in Biogen’s Neurodegeneration Research Unit.  He is responsible for developing and driving a diverse preclinical portfolio of programs, to complement Biogen’s development efforts for their a-synuclein antibody, which is in Phase 2 trials, using multiple modalities, from antibodies and antisense oligonucleotides, in collaboration in Ionis, to gene therapy and small molecules, targeting mechanisms strongly supported by human genetics and pathology, to deliver novel disease-modifying therapeutics to patients.  Warren has 22 years of industry experience, working for GlaxoSmithKline, Wyeth, Pfizer and now Biogen.

biography.iv: Maria Grazia Spillantini is Professor of Molecular Neurology in the Department of Clinical Neurosciences at the University of Cambridge. Her interest is on alpha-synucleinopathies and tauopathies. With her collaborators, she identified alpha-synuclein as the component of the filaments that form the Lewy bodies in Parkinson’s disease, dementia with Lewy bodies and the glial inclusions in multiple system atrophy and described one of the first mutations in the MAPT gene causing frontotemporal dementia. She has received several awards and is a Fellow of the Royal Society and Knight Officer of the Star of Italy.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Maria Grazia has expertise in protein aggregation, transgenic mouse models, human iPSCs, molecular neuropathology of tau and alpha-synuclein related diseases in human brain

researchInterests.iv: Maria Grazia is interested in alpha-synuclein and tau aggregation and how these affect neurones and glia cells  leading to neurodegeneration and disease development

responsibilities.iv: Maria Grazia will be responsible to investigate how alpha-synuclein  spreading can be affected by modulating genes involved in disease progression. In a new transgenic mouse model where spreading occurs from gut to brain it will be investigate the rate of alpha-synuclein spreading, the forms of alpha-synuclein that are involved in spreading, the cells that are affected in the process and how the arrival of alpha-synuclein affects cellular mechanisms that could be involved in disease development.

biography.iv: Anna is a PhD student in Joanne Jones' Therapeutic Immunology Group in the Department of Clinical Neurosciences, University of Cambridge. She graduated from the University of Manchester with a BSc in Biomedical Sciences with a year working at the University of L'Aquila (Italy) in the Applied Clinical Sciences & Biotechnology Department. During her degree, Anna worked on characterising classically- and alternatively-activated human lung macrophages as well as describing the neuronal, and other extra-skeletal, phenotype associated with a rare bone disease Autosomal Dominant Osteoporosis type 2.

responsibilities.iv: Working in the Jones Lab Therapeutic Immunology Group, Anna will be performing bulk Nanostring gene expression analysis of post-mortem PD patient brains to understand the neuroinflammatory environment and glial activation.

biography.iv: Monther Abu-Remaileh, PhD, is an assistant professor of chemical engineering and by courtesy of genetics at Stanford University. He is an expert in lysosome biology and metabolism, and his team develops and uses multidisciplinary approaches, including metabolomics, proteomics and functional genomics, to study the biochemical functions of the lysosome. His lab is committed to applying these tools to provide molecular understanding of the lysosomal dysfunction in Parkinson's disease, which has been implicated in disease pathology.  Dr. Abu-Remaileh earned his B.Sc. in Genetics from Jordan University of Science and Technology and his doctorate from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and then completed his postdoctoral training at MIT.

biography.iv: Carolyn is a Professor in the Department of Neurogenetics at the Kolling Institute, University of Sydney and at Royal North Shore Hospital in Sydney. She is an MRFF NHMRC Practitioner Fellow. She studied medicine at the University of New South Wales, Sydney Australia and completed her PhD at University of Sydney. She undertook her post-doctoral training at Columbia University (where she was mentored by Salvatore DiMauro, Eric Schon and Stan Fahn). She was awarded an Order of Australia Honour (AM) for her contributions to medicine in 2019 and was admitted to the Australian Academy of Health and Medical Research as a Fellow in 2020.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Carolyn is a clinician-scientist with >25 years clinical experience in Parkinson's disease, molecular and genetic research. Her lab investigates the role of mitochondrial function in health and disease and uses patient derived cell models to study disease mechanisms and identify drug targets.

researchInterests.iv: Carolyn is interested in how Parkinson's Disease-related gene mutations and mitochondrial function contribute to the disease process in Parkinson's disease.

responsibilities.iv: Carolyn will be responsible for the genetic analysis of the iPSCs used in this project. She and her team will perform whole genome sequencing analysis to confirm the presence and absence of PD gene mutations before and after gene-editing. She will also be responsible for assessing mitochondrial function in the cultured neurons and astrocytes generated from the iPSCs.

biography.iv: Nick Wood is clinician scientist and professor of Neurology and Genetics at UCL London. He has worked in complex trait and single gene analyses since his graduate work in the genetics of multiple sclerosis at the University of Cambridge. He undertook post-doctoral work with Anita Harding at UCL Institute of Neurology. He has led the neurogenic service at the National Hospital Queen Square London since 1995. He was appointed to the Galton Chair of genetics at UCL in 2009

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Nick has worked in genetics of PD for over 25 years. He has extensive experience of finding genes and genetic risk factors (GWAS) in PD.

researchInterests.iv: Nick is interested in genes and genomic processes that lead to Parkinson's.

responsibilities.iv: Nick will apply a range of genetic approaches to understanding the complex interaction between DNA encoded risk (single genes and genetic risk factors) and the transcriptome (and other omics) in human brain cells. He will build on his experience on working in PD genetics and conducting GWAS and single gene studies to prioritise genomic events for further study. He is also responsible as PI for th overall propagation of the program.

biography.iv: Frank is Assistant Professor in the Departments of Neuroscience and Genetics and a member of the Ruth L. and David S. Gottesman Institute for Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He received his MD from the University of Tübingen in Germany. For his thesis under the guidance of Jörg Schulz he investigated the molecular mechanism of cellular death in dopaminergic neurons as model for Parkinson’s disease. In his postdoctoral research with Ron McKay at NINDS/NIH and Rudolf Jaenisch at the Whitehead Institute at MIT, he established novel human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC)-based experimental paradigms to dissect the genetic basis of Parkinson’s disease.

iv.question: Do familial and sporadic forms of Parkinson’s disease share common pathobiologies?

researchInterests.iv: Frank’s lab is trying to understand how genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors are integrated on a molecular and cellular level to contribute to the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s disease.

responsibilities.iv: Frank and his team will genetically engineer isogenic hPSCs carrying familial PD mutations to analyze transcriptional changes in monolayer and organoid neuronal cultures using bulk and single-cell RNA sequencing. In addition, Frank and his team will establish Perturb-seq approaches in organoids to identify transcriptional changes and genetic interactions associated with GWAS risk loci in single cells resulting from CRISPR knock-down or activation of more than 300 GWAS-nominated target genes.

biography.iv: Jim is a Professor in the Department of Molecular and Cell Biology, University of California. He trained with structural biologists Robert Stroud and Brian Matthews, and was an investigator in the NIH intramural program before joining UC Berkeley. He is best known for structural and reconstitution studies of the machinery of endosome, lysosome, and autophagosome biogenesis.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Jim has thirty years of experience in structural biology and ten years in the areas of autophagy and biophysical membrane reconstitution.

researchInterests.iv: Jim in interested in autophagy, endosomes, lysosomes, membrane reconstitution, and structural biology.

responsibilities.iv: Jim is the coordinating PI for the overall team and will lead efforts in his own lab to use structural biology and membrane biophysics to elucidate mechanisms of Parkin and PINK1-dependent mitophagy.

biography.iv: David is the Edgerly Professor and Chairman Department of Neurology and Professor of Immunobiology, Yale School of Medicine.  As a physician-scientist, David has made seminal discoveries defining the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis and autoimmunity; his investigations identified human autoreactive T cells and the mechanisms that underlie their dysregulation including the discovery of human regulatory T cells. He led the discovery of genetic variants causing MS and demonstrated how these variants alter immune responses.  David was a Jacob Javits Merit Award Recipient from the NIH and was awarded the Dystel Prize for MS research from the AAN, the Adams Prize from the ANA and was elected to membership in the AOA Society, the ASCI, and the National Academy of Medicine.

He will apply his experience investigating T cell responses to auto-antigens in the CSF using new technologies including MHC class II tetramers and single cell RNA seq. His team's work is focused on generating pre-clinical human data that will lead to a clinical trial to treat patients with early Parkinson's Disease.

researchInterests.iv: David has spent his career interrogating immune responses to self-antigens in the central nervous system.

researchInterests.iv: Darren is interested in the bidirectional relationship between cellular senescence and late-onset PD genes, such as LRRK2 and VPS35, in brain cells.

biography.iv: Ana Luisa Gil Martinez is a Postdoctoral Research Fellow in the Ryten lab. She completed her Bachelor's in Biochemistry (2010-2014) and her Master’s Degree in Molecular Biology and Biotechnology (2014-2015) at the University of Murcia (Spain). Her thesis was focused on the study of the involvement of glial cells in the neurodegenerative processes associated with Parkinsonism and aging. In 2019, she obtained a Double Doctor's degree by the University of Murcia (Spain) and Maastricht University (The Netherlands). Currently, her postdoctoral project in the Ryten Lab aims to integrate co-expression models to investigate molecular mechanisms driving the progression of Parkinson's disease.

biography.iv: Deniz is a Professor of Neuroscience at Lund University and Honorary Professor at the University of Sydney. He has over 2 decades of experience and track record in the fields of cell and gene therapy with special focus on development of technologies for treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. His developed recombinant AAV vectors towards therapeutic delivery and for disease modeling in rodents and non-human primates. He has pioneered PD animal model based on the use of AAV vectors to express alpha-synuclein in nigral dopamine neurons. Furthermore, he has directed studies aimed at understanding the pathophysiological basis of L-DOPA induced dyskinesias and how advanced treatments using cell and gene-based therapies could alleviate these troubling side effects of oral L-DOPA medication.

responsibilities.iv: Deniz will be responsible from in vivo studies where patient-derived iPSCs will be grafted to mouse models and followed long term. His team will assess the biochemical signatures of the diseased neurons and astrocytes in the brain. He will coordinate the generation of the gene-edited lines that will be created in the course of the project by several members of the team.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Deniz has over 2 decades of experience in cell and gene based therapies in Parkinson's disease.

researchInterests.iv: Deniz is interested in pathobiology of Parkinson's disease and in that context uses patient-derived stem cells, recombinant viral vectors and novel animal models to help develop better treatments.

biography.iv: Christina is a post-doctoral research associate working at Queen Square Brain Bank for neurological disorders for the last 10 years. She has expertise in Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease and neuroinflammation, completing a PhD titled 'The role of TREM2 in neurodegeneration'. She uses her pathological expertise and combines this with multi-omic approaches to determine the changes in protein/lipid expression linked to pathological aggregation. She aims to lead her own research group in the future.

She will be responsible for performing the immunofluorescence for oligomeric alpha-synuclein and a range of cell markers before sending to Cambridge to image with super-resolution techniques. Christina will also work with a sequencing team to perform bulk RNAseq, snRNAseq, snATACseq and long-read RNAseq on the same samples.

biography.iv: Dr. Johnston has been studying neurodegenerative disease for the last 20 years, starting with her work with Dr. R. Kopito at Stanford which resulted in the discovery  of Aggresomes. At Elan Pharmaceuticals, Dr. Johnston studied protein folding and cellular proteostasis for basic research and drug discovery for PD. In addition to VP Head of Exploratory Research, Dr. Johnston also identified small molecule therapeutics for Parkin E3 ligase, reported the first high resolution crystal structure of the Parkin protein, and determined Parkin functions as a new category of ligase.  Presently, Dr. Johnston is Co-Founder and CEO of NysnoBio, a Biotech company focused on the modulation of the Parkin enzyme pathway for critical unmet medical needs in Neurology and Oncology.

biography.iv: Prof Stefan Knapp studied Chemistry at the University of Marburg (Germany) and at the University of Illinois (USA). He did his PhD in protein crystallography at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm. In 1999, he joined the Pharmacia and left the company in 2004 to set up a research group at the Structural Genomics Consortium at Oxford University. From 2008 to 2015 he was a Professor of Structural Biology at Oxford University (UK) and from 2012 to 2015 the director for Chemical Biology at the Target Discovery Institute at Oxford University. He joined Frankfurt University in 2015 as a Professor of Pharmaceutical Chemistry. Since 2017 he is also the CSO of the SGC (Structure Genomics Consortium) node at the Goethe-University Frankfurt.

biography.iv: Peter Vangheluwe is an Associate Professor in the Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine at KU Leuven in Belgium, and is head of the Laboratory of Cellular Transport Systems. Using biochemical and molecular cell biology approaches, he characterizes new P-type transport ATPases that regulate polyamine homeostasis and lipid distribution in the cell. He discovered that ATP13A2/PARK9 works as a lysosomal polyamine transporter, and that ATP10B operates as a lysosomal glucosylceramide exporter. He published >60 peer-reviewed publications and received two awards by the Queen Elisabeth Foundation for Neurosciences in Belgium.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Peter is an associate professor and molecular cell biologist experienced in the biochemical properties and cellular role of lysosomal transporters involved in polyamine and lipid homeostasis.

responsibilities.iv: Peter will be the coordinating principal investigator and main responsible of the ASAP project IMPACT-PD. His current work is focused on the lysosomal transporters ATP13A2 and ATP10B, which are genetically implicated in Parkinson's disease. biography.iv: Agnete Kirkeby is an Associate Professor and group leader at the Department of Neuroscience at University of Copenhagen (Denmark) and at the Wallenberg Center for Molecular Medicine at Lund University (Sweden). Agnete and her group has unique expertise in using human pluripotent stem cells for production of subtype-specific human neurons. This work has led to the development of a promising stem cell treatment for Parkinson’s Disease (PD), which is moving towards clinical trial. The Kirkeby group further studies early brain development using human stem cell and advanced microfluidic culturing techniques to model the developing neural tube of humans, and produce various different types of neurons for use in regenerative therapy and disease modelling.

biography.iv: Xianjun Dong is an Assistant Professor at Harvard Medical School and leads the Genomics and Bioinformatics Hub at Brigham and Women's Hospital. He received his Ph.D. degree in Bioinformatics at the University of Bergen (supervisor: Boris Lenhard). He has been the Director of Computational Neuroscience of the Precision Neurology Program (Director: Clemens Scherzer, MD) at Brigham and Women's Hospital since 2013, leading the Bioinformatics team working on neurodegenerative diseases including Parkinson's disease. He is particularly interested in the non-coding RNAs (miRNA, eRNA, circRNA, etc.) and their functions in the brain. Dr. Dong is also awarded by the American Parkinson Disease Association (APDA).

responsibilities.iv: Xianjun will derive the cis-regulatory effects of 6000 GWAS variants using 5D-eQTL analysis across cell types, disease stage, and brain space. His team will identify eQTLs that are active in specific cell types. They will also identify eQTLs that are enhanced during a specific disease stage. The output of 5D-eQTL analysis will be integrated into an open-source visualization system. Significant eQTLs will be rigorously replicated in an independent cohort with ~1000 human brains.

biography.iv: Erika is the William Maul Measey Professor of Physiology at the University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine.  She received her B.S. in Chemistry and History from the College of William and Mary, her PhD in Biochemistry from Penn State, and performed her postdoctoral studies in cell biology at the Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology. Erika has received a Porter Fellowship, the NINDS Javits Award, the Stanley N. Cohen Biomedical Research Award and the Jane M. Glick Graduate Student Teaching Award.  She is an inaugural Lifetime Fellow of the ASCB and was awarded the 2020 ASCB Sandra K. Masur Senior Leadership Award. She has trained more than 40 postdocs and students, many now on faculties at major research institutes.

biography.iv: Michela Deleidi studied medicine at Vita-Salute University, San Raffaele Scientific Institute, Milan, Italy. She completed her residency in neurology followed by a fellowship at Harvard Medical School. She focused on pluripotent stem cell technology for Parkinson's disease (PD) modeling and regenerative medicine applications. She was awarded an Alexander von Humboldt Fellowship and she relocated to Germany to pursue her PhD studies at the DZNE in Tübingen. By combining cellular reprogramming with genome editing, her work led to one of the first stem cell-based models of PD, clearly showing a mechanistic link with lysosomal storage diseases. Since 2016, Michela Deleidi is a Helmholtz Young Investigator at DZNE and an assistant professor of Neurology at the University of Tübingen.

researchInterests.iv: Michela's research focuses on the role of the immune system as an early trigger of Parkinson's disease. She combines in vivo with in vitro systems (iPSC-derived macrophages/microglia and organoids).

biography.iv: Dino is a Professor and Senior Research Group Leader at the German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE) in Bonn, Germany. Prior to moving to Germany, he spent most of his research career at the Parkinson's Institute in Sunnyvale, California, where he acted as Director of Fundamental Research from 1997 to 2010. Dino is currently also Deputy Scientific Director of the DZNE-Bonn.

biography.iv: Alex is a Professor in the Center for Infectious Diseases and Vaccine Research at the La Jolla Institute in La Jolla, CA. Over his career, Alex and his team have discovered and characterized how MHC variants can be grouped according to broad functional specificities, greatly facilitating epitope classification and understanding the basic rules of epitope-MHC interactions. Alex helped develop and currently runs the Immune Epitope Database (IEDB), freely available to the scientific community, which hosts immune reactivity data, and bioinformatics tools to assist in the prediction and evaluation of immune responses. His lab has been involved in hundreds of epitope identification studies, resulting in thousands of T cell epitopes, which has been shared with the public through the IEDB.

biography.iv: Chris Van den Haute is a research expert in the Department of Neurosciences, University of Leuven, Belgium. He studied biology, did his PhD in the Alzheimer's Disease (AD) field where he generated transgenic mice to study AD mechanisms and started a post-doc in the Research Group of Neurobiology and Gene Therapy on AD and Parkinson's disease. From a specific topic on PINK1 he evolved into more technology development with a focus on viral vector technology.

iv.question: How can we improve specificity of viral vectors?

researchInterests.iv: Chris is a research expert with focus on viral vector technology and use of these viral vectors to generate cellular and animal models for Parkinson's disease.

responsibilities.iv: Chris will optimize and generate viral vectors as tools to create new cellular and animal models. He has a lot of experience to generate stable cell lines using lentiviral vectors (LV) with overexpression or knock-down of proteins or combinations of both. Validated  constructs can be converted to adeno-associated viral vectors (AAV) to be used in an animal model.

biography.iv: Jyoti Adlakha is a Postdoctoral Associate under the mentorship of Prof. Karin Reinisch in the Department of Cell Biology, Yale University. She completed her doctoral studies with Prof. Andrei Lupas at the Max Planck Institute for Developmental Biology, Germany.

researchInterests.iv: Jyoti is interested in protein-mediated inter-organelle lipid transport at membrane contact sites.

responsibilities.iv: Jyoti will employ structural biology tools, X-ray crystallography and cryo-electron microscopy, and biochemical approaches to investigate the molecular mechanism of protein-mediated lipid trafficking between organelles at close apposition sites, particularly for genes involved in maintaining mitochondrial homeostasis and integrity and whose loss-of-function mutations result in severe neurodegenerative disorders including early-onset Parkinson’s disease.

biography.iv: Marta obtained her Bachelor´s degree in Biochemistry from the Complutense University of Madrid (Spain) and her Master´s degree in Biophysics from Autonomous University of Madrid. Then, as a graduate student in Carlos Fernández Tornero´s laboratory at the Biological Research Center Margarita Salas – CSIC (Madrid), she studied the mechanistic basis of RNA polymerase I damage recognition in the presence of a UV-light induced lesion. Marta is now a postdoctoral researcher in Andres Leschziner´s laboratory at University of California San Diego.

researchInterests.iv: Marta is interested in understanding the molecular mechanisms and dynamics involved in LRRK2-mediated Parkinson´s disease.

responsibilities.iv: Marta applies molecular biology, biophysical and structural techniques to characterize LRRK2 complexes. His work was supported by a prestigious doctoral fellowship offered by the CanHepC, CIHR. He also received several travel and presentation awards. Ahmed is currently leading projects in Dr. Desjardins's lab that aim at exploring the role of mitochondrial antigen presentation in PD pathogenesis.

biography.iv: My name is Oriol Busquets Figueras. Currently, I'm a Postdoctoral Fellow at the Dominick P. Purpura Department of Neuroscience of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. biography.iv: Catherine is an MBPhD student at University College London. She began her medical school degree in 2014, and completed an intercalated Bachelor’s degree in Neuroscience in 2017. Among her awards are the Burnstock and HAB Simons prizes for the highest mark on the UCL Neuroscience iBSc and for the most outstanding laboratory-based iBSc project. In 2014 she was awarded the ECIS Award for International Understanding for having a "positive attitude toward the life and culture of others ... with the ability to bring differing people together into a sense of community".

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Catherine has a medical education background, and her research skills are mostly within bioinformatics, such as Mendelian randomization, GWAS quality control, polygenic risk score analyses, as well as exome and genome sequencing analyses. researchInterests.iv: Catherine's research interests focus on using genetics to understand and develop treatments for Parkinson’s disease.

responsibilities.iv: Catherine's work involves (1) using Mendelian randomization to identify new drugs for Parkinson's disease, (2) using the chromosome conformation capture technology Hi-C to identify DNA-to-DNA interactions of Parkinson’s disease risk loci, and (3) studying the relationship between the genetic risk of Parkinson’s disease and post-mortem neuropathology burden.

biography.iv:
Guillermo is a postdoctoral fellow at the Desjardins laboratory, Université de Montréal. He completed his graduate studies, and first postdoctoral fellowship, at the INRS–Centre Armand-Frappier under the supervision of Dr. A. Descoteaux. He discovered how Leishmania virulence factors co-opt the host cell’s secretory pathway in order to transport its virulence factors beyond the phagosome. Moreover, Guillermo elucidated the role of Parkinson's disease-associated protein Synaptotagmin XI (SytXI) in macrophage cytokine secretion. He showed that Leishmania benefits from degrading SytXI in order to augment the release of TNF and IL-6. 

Guillermo has received awards from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research, the Fonds de recherche du Québec, and the Institut Pasteur International Network.

biography.iv: Josh obtained his PhD at Birkbeck in London (UK), where he studied the COPII membrane trafficking coat using biochemical reconstitution and structural biology. With cryo-electron tomography and subtomogram averaging, he solved several structures of COPII bound to membranes to understand mechanisms of assembly and curvature induction. He is currently a postdoctoral fellow with Elizabeth Villa, where he aims to resolve protein-membrane interfaces within cells.

biography.iv: Caroline Williams-Gray is a Principal Research Associate in the Department of Clinical Neurosciences at the University of Cambridge, UK, and an honorary consultant neurologist, specializing in Parkinson’s disease and movement disorders. She studied medicine at Cambridge University and Oxford Clinical School, and subsequently gained her PhD from Cambridge for work on the cognitive heterogeneity of Parkinson’s disease. Following completion of a Clinical Lectureship in Neurology, she was awarded an MRC Clinician Scientist Fellowship in 2018. She now leads a translational research group investigating the basis of heterogeneity in Parkinson’s and the role of the immune system in this condition.

biography.iv:
Matt is a Senior Research Fellow in the Department of Clinical and Movement Neuroscience at UCL Queen Square Intistute of Neurology.

responsibilities.iv: Michael will study interactions between alpha-synuclein (A-SYN), glucocerebrosidase (GBA) and the microbiome in enteroendocrine cells in vitro. HuTu-80 (human) and STC-1 (murine) enteroendocrine cell lines express A-SYN. He will use these cells to determine the expression of A-SYN upon exposure to specific microbial factors, CsgA monomers, curli fibrils and TLR2 and 4 inhibitors and will knock-in the L444P and N370S GBA mutations to study the effect of these factors on GBA mutant STC-1 cells.

biography.iv: John is a postdoctoral scholar at Caltech with a unique, cross-disciplinary combination of engineering and wet lab skills. After finishing undergraduate studies in electrical engineering and computer science at MIT, John applied his training at Honeywell, working on inertial guidance systems for the military and Atlas V launch vehicle. His computational background supports studies with the analysis of sequencing data. In his PhD studies with Dr. Liang Zhou at Northwestern University, John studied the mechanisms underlying the impact of environmental factors on immunity, focusing on the regulation of lymphoid cells by the microbiome in health and disease. John continues his work at a time when data suggest a significant role for peripheral immune responses in neurodegenerative diseases.

biography.iv: Professor Dario Alessi serves as the Director of the MRC Protein Phosphorylation and Ubiquitylation Unit at the University of Dundee. His research focuses on unravelling the roles of poorly characterised components which regulate human disease resulting from disruption of signalling networks. He has contributed to our understanding of several disease relevant signal transduction pathways including PDK1 (diabetes and cancer), LKB1 (cancer), WNKs (blood pressure). Much of Dario’s current work is focused on understanding LRRK2 and how mutations in this enzyme cause Parkinson’s disease.

biography.iv: Minee is a Neurophysiologist in the Francis Crick Institute and UCL Institute of Neurology, London. Her research is focused on understanding neuropathology (alpha-synuclein aggregation, inflammation and mitochondrial dysfunction) in Parkinson's disease using biophysics and human iPSC model. She has recently focused on  a Bio-AI project to predict disease state of PD using machine learning which can provide advanced benefit for development of therapeutics.

biography.iv: Mahalakshmi Somayaji is an Associate Research Scientist at the Sulzer Lab, Department of Psychiatry, Columbia University, New York. Her research is involved in understanding synuclein-dependent dopamine signaling in physiological and pathological conditions. She completed her PhD from Roeper Lab, University of Frankfurt, Germany, where her research aimed at investigating the electrophysiological changes of dopamine neurons in the pre-symptomatic stages of Parkinson disease.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Maha has several years of experience in in vivo electrophysiology, electrochemistry, rodent behaviour and histology.

researchInterests.iv: Maha is interested in understanding the endogenous role of synuclein in dopamine signaling in vivo.

biography.iv: Su-Chun Zhang received his MD (1984) and MS (1989) in China, and PhD (1996) in Canada. Following postdoctoral training, he began his assistant professor in 2001 and is now Steenbock Professor in Behavioral and Neural Sciences at University of Wisconsin-Madison. He is also professor and director of the Signature Program in Neuroscience and Behavioral Disorders at Duke-NUS Medical School, Singapore. His group has developed technology to guide human pluripotent stem cells to functionally specialized nerve cell types. He is dissecting mechanisms of and developing therapeutics for neurological conditions like Parkinson’s disease. Dr. Zhang is a founder of the WiCell Institute and BrainXell, Inc.

biography.iv: Dr. Bernard Thienpont is a Professor in the Department of Human Genetics, University of Leuven, where he heads the Laboratory for Functional Epigenetics. He studied cardiogenetics as a graduate student with Koen Devriendt in Leuven, cardiac epigenetics as a Marie Curie fellow with Llew Roderick and Wolf Reik in Cambridge, UK, and cancer epigenetics as an FWO fellow with Diether Lambrechts at the VIB, Belgium.

biography.iv: Heidi is a graduate of McGill (B.Sc ’91, Ph.D with Gordon Shore in ’96) and completed post-doctoral training in the lab of Marino Zerial at the EMBL in Heidelberg, Germany in 2000. She trained in the fields of mitochondrial protein import and the molecular mechanisms of endocytosis, Rab activation and SNARE assembly. As an independent investigator, her group has focused on understanding the fundamental behaviour of the mitochondria and how they are integrated into the cellular environment. She started her independent career at the University of Ottawa Heart Institute (2000-2011), and then moved to McGill University where she is now a Full Professor in the Department of Neurology and Neurosurgery within the Rare Neurological Disease Group at the Montreal Neurological Institute.

responsibilities.iv: The McBride lab will help map the functions of 5 distinct PD related proteins along the cell biological and signaling processes triggered in response to infection. Initially in primary professional antigen presenting cell models, the work will expand into additional cell systems and coculture models.

biography.iv: At the moment, Koen is a lab engineer in the Laboratory of Computational Biology (VIB-KU Leuven) of Stein Aerts. responsibilities.iv: Koen will be responsible for processing the ASAP brain samples. He will subject the samples to linked- and long-read whole-genome sequencing in order to retrieve SNP-allele haplotype structures of each donor. Each sample will also be used in a single-cell multiome assay to profile both the open chromatin and transcriptome of single cells. The whole-genome and single-cell datasets will be integrated to study e/caQTLs.

A particular focus of his current work is the reconstitution of key steps of selective autophagy and eventually the reconstitution of the entire process. To this end, he is studying the yeast cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting pathway as well as aggrephagy and mitophagy in mammalian cells.

biography.iv: Prof. Stein Aerts has a multidisciplinary background in both bio-engineering and computer science. During his PhD he was trained in bioinformatics, and during his Postdoc he worked on the genomics of gene regulation in Drosophila. Stein’s lab focuses on deciphering the genomic regulatory code, using a combination of single-cell, machine-learning, and experimental approaches. Stein co-founded the Fly Cell Atlas consortium and generated a single-cell atlas of the ageing Drosophila brain. He holds an ERC Consolidator Grant and was awarded the 2017 Prize for Bioinformatics and Computational Science from the Biotech Fund and the 2016 Astrazeneca Foundation Award Bioinformatics.

researchInterests.iv: Stein is interested in cellular states and genome regulation.

biography.iv: Chris is a postdoctoral researcher in the lab of Stein Aerts at VIB-KU Leuven in Belgium. He completed his PhD in 2016 at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in Bronx, NY. His thesis research focused on a bioinformatics analysis of patterns of meiotic recombination in the human genome using a large collection of human family data. Chris has worked on a variety of research topics including population genetics, personalized medicine, ageing, disease risk prediction, cancer, and he contributed to the 1000 Genomes (Phase 3) study.

responsibilities.iv: Chris will be responsible for managing the bioinformatics analysis of both whole genome and single cell multiomics datasets at KU Leuven, Belgium. With this data, we aim to investigate specific regions of the genome, including inherited and acquired variation, with known involvement in Parkinson's Disease. We will explore how this underlying DNA variation affects gene expression across various cell types and how this relationship is affected with age and other compounding factors.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Chris has years of experience in bioinformatics analysis of human genomes, and he has used whole genome sequencing analysis to answer research questions in population genetics, ageing, personalized medicine, and disease risk prediction.

researchInterests.iv: Chris’s background is in human genetics and he currently works on bioinformatics analysis of single cell sequencing data (RNA, ATAC), with a focus on how gene regulatory networks define cell type.

biography.iv: Ana is a Postdoctoral researcher in the laboratory of Prof. Vangheluwe, Catholic University of Leuven, Belgium. As a graduate student she studied the impact of Dystonia-causing mutations on mammalian brain lipid metabolism. During her work she identified abnormal Phosphatidate metabolism as the main driver of disease phenotypes, and patented Phosphatidate phosphatase inhibition as a new and feasible therapeutic target for Dystonia.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Beatrice has experience in several genetic and cell biology laboratory techniques as well as basic programming and data analysis skills.

researchInterests.iv: Beatrice's interests lie at the intersection of bioinformatics, genetic and functional analyses to help highlighting molecular targets to be used for developing  therapeutic measures in FTD.

responsibilities.iv: After having developed a bioinformatics pipeline which integrates multi-omics data (gene co-expression and protein-protein interaction data), Beatrice prioritised 3 genes/proteins targets are highly shared by FTD mendelian genes and are enriched for FTD-risk processes, suggesting that they may hold functional relevance in FTD. She will be modelling these proteins in the context of mitophagy/autophagy pathways to characterise the 3 candidate proteins in a disease-relevant (FTD) model.

biography.iv: Dan is an MD/PhD candidate in Dr. Erika Holzbaur's lab at the University of Pennsylvania. He later studied congenital pain disorders using iPSC-derived neuron models as a research assistant in Dr. Clifford Woolf's lab at Boston Children's Hospital.

researchInterests.iv: Yue is interested in LRRK2 models, cellular senescence, and neuroinflammation.

responsibilities.iv: Yue will be responsible for testing the hypothesis that PD-linked LRRK2 mutants cause cellular senescence and blocking senescence will provide neuroprotection by determining whether: (1) PD-linked mutations in LRRK2 induce cellular senescence in the rodent brain, (2) increased senescence can exacerbate or unmask PD-like neurodegenerative phenotypes in LRRK2 mouse models, and (3) if removing senescent cells will provide neuroprotection in LRRK2 rodent models of PD.

After graduating with a thesis on the structural characterization of the interaction between PINK1 and Beclin 1 (Supervisors: Prof EM Valente, Prof E Gherardi), he was awarded the Edoardo Balbi Fellowship to continue research on the subject.

After obtaining a degree in Pharmaceutical Sciences in Portugal, he obtained his PhD from the Autonomous University of Madrid (Spain) working in Carlos Fernandez-Tornero’s laboratory, where he investigated the recruitment of yeast RNA polymerase I to rDNA promoters. He then joined Bruno Klaholz’s team (Strasbourg, France) to focus on a nucleosome complex which forms a key functional unit in chromatin.

researchInterests.iv: Jaime is interested in the role of LRRK2 in normal and dysfunctional cells and in applying innovative structural biology techniques to understand the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s Disease.

responsibilities.iv: Jaime’s background in structural biology, especially in cryo-electron microscopy, will allow him to determine structures of biologically relevant LRRK2 complexes. biography.iv: Dr. Cátia Moutinho is a group Leader at the Garvan-Weizmann Centre for Cellular Genomics, at the Garvan Institute. Her team focuses on single-cell genomics development. She is a biologist by training, with a PhD in Biomedicine and a master in Clinical Trials and Medical Affairs. She has an extensive experience in the wet-lab, with a strong background in single-cell technology, as well as cancer genetics and epigenetics. She has more than 45 scientific publications in peer-reviewed journals including original papers and a book chapter. After starting her professional career in Oporto, Portugal, and working in Madrid and Barcelona for more than 10 years, she decided to embark on a new journey in Sydney, Australia where she is currently residing.

researchInterests.iv: Fokion is interested in molecular mechanisms of neurodegeneration, specifically Parkinson's disease, using novel in vitro modelling methods (i.e. iPSC-induced neurons, brain organoids).

responsibilities.iv: Fokion will be responsible for studying how bacterial amyloids induce alpha-synuclein aggregation in midbrain organoids carrying different GBA mutations. His current team work focuses on studying how inflammation and GBA mutations influence Parkinson disease pathology from a molecular perspective.

biography.iv: Ted is Scientific Director of the Montreal Neurological Institute and Professor in the Department of Neurology and Neurosurgery at McGill University. He is a Clinician-Scientist and attending neurologist specializing in movement disorders. He is the Director of the FRQS Quebec Parkinson Network (http://rpq-qpn.ca/en/). Ted helped establish the Tanenbaum Open Science Institute (TOSI) at the MNI (https://www.mcgill.ca/neuro/open-science) and oversee its platforms including the Clinical Biological Imaging and Genetic repository (C-BIGr; https://www.mcgill.ca/c-bigneuro/) and iPSC/CRISPR Early Drug Discovery Unit (EDDU; https://www.mcgill.ca/neuro/open-science/open-science-platforms/eddu).

iv.question: Do the various PD genes interact in a common cellular pathway?
Which genes within the various PD GWAS loci drive disease association?
What is the contribution of to various genes within the PD GWAS loci to disease pathogenesis?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Ted has expertise in studying the function of PD genes, including Parkin, PINK1, GBA, α-synuclein, LRRK2, and TMEM175. He has established the infrastructure to study these PD gene in human patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells, differentiated into neurons, glia and 3D brain organoids.

researchInterests.iv: Ted is interested in the function and cell biology of PD genes. He has focused on how Parkin and PINK1, two proteins encoded by recessive PD genes, regulate mitochondrial quality control.

responsibilities.iv: Ted oversee the Clinical Biological Imaging and Genetic repository (C-BIGr; https://www.mcgill.ca/c-bigneuro/) at the Montreal Neurological Institute and will be responsible for providing bio samples required for this project. As Director of the FRQS Quebec Parkinson Network (http://rpq-qpn.ca/en/), Ted has led an initiative to recruit nearly 2000 patients with PD and RBD into C-BIGr and to collect bio samples and derive iPSCs from these patients.

biography.iv: Mujahid Azfar is a molecular and cell biology PhD student at KU Leuven where his main project aim is investigating ATP13A3 and its potential link to Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension. Having been affiliated with the Laboratory of Cellular Transport Systems for almost 4 years and having also worked on notable P-type ATPases such as ATP13A2 and SERCA2a, Mujahid has acquired experience in a vast array of protein characterization techniques.

iv.question: Can we pin-point ATP13A2's On/Off switch?
Given the high level of conservation amongst the P5B-ATPases, in finding how to modulate the activity of ATP13A2, could a similar approach  be used to target other members of the protein sub-family?

researchInterests.iv: Mujahid is interested in the autoregulation of ATP13A2 and ATP13A3 and also their cellular role in polyamine homeostasis.

responsibilities.iv: Mujahid will be responsible for exploring methods of modulating ATP13A2's activity by studying its autoregulatory mechanism. This would entail studying the impact of the N/C-termini as well as short peptides and/or antibodies on ATP13A2 activity with the end goal of being tested in a cellular context so as to be useful for target validation. Mujahid will also contribute to the protein purification taskforce at the Vangheluwe lab.

biography.iv: Veerle is a professor in the Department of Neurosciences at the KU Leuven in Belgium. She has a PhD degree in neurobiology from the KU Leuven in 1995. During her PhD she obtained a Frank Boas Fulbright fellowship for a research visit in Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School. She was appointed as an assistant professor and head of the Laboratory for Neurobiology and Gene Therapy at the faculty of medicine at KU Leuven in 2003.  In collaboration with the virologist Dr. Zeger Debyser, they were the first research groups to introduce viral vector technology in Belgium. She has acquired international recognition for the application of viral vectors in rodent brain to model and study PD and more recently for demonstrating a prion-like behaviour of the α-synuclein protein.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Veerle has extensive expertise in viral vector-based cellular and rodent models for PD, with a focus on alpha-synuclein and LRRK2

researchInterests.iv: Veerle is interested in the molecular pathogenesis of PD and related disorders based on genetic links to the disease, with a focus on alpha-synuclein and LRRK2

responsibilities.iv: Veerle will be investigating the role of ATP13A2 and ATP10B in cellular and animal PD models of alpha-synuclein toxicity. In addition she will design and produce viral vectors for the other project partners.

institution.iv: IRCCS Mondino Foundation, National Institute of Neurology, Pavia, Italy

biography.iv: Fabio Blandini is currently Scientific Director of the Mondino National Institute of Neurology - a research hospital funded by the Italian Ministry of Health - and full professor of neuropharmacology at the Dept. of Brain and Behavioral Sciences of the University of Pavia. He is also chair of the Pan-European Committee of IBRO (https://ibro.org/pan-europe-committee/) and member of the European Brain Council (https://www.braincouncil.eu/about-us/full-members/). He obtained his MD degree in 1986, then specialized in neurology in 1990 and biochemistry in 2001. His research interests are focused on the investigation of the pathogenesis and the search for innovative therapeutics of Parkinson’s disease through pre-clinical models and clinical studies in patients.

researchInterests.iv: Long-standing interest in PD pathogenesis and search for innovative therapeutics  through pre-clinical models and clinical studies in patients. Currently focused on the correlations between PD and GBA

responsibilities.iv: FB will provide part of the patients’ cohorts and control subjects necessary for the study. Saliva, stool and urine samples will be collected and sent to INRAE for the microbiome study, whose results will be correlated with clinical and biochemical parameters. FB’s group will analyse plasma alpha-synuclein levels (free and exosome-associated), pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokines and a set of lysosomal proteins in PBMCs including GCase, LIMP-2, saposin C and cathepsin D.

biography.iv: Sonia is a Professor of Neurology at UCL, and a Group Leader at The Francis Crick Institute. She studied the role of PINK1 in autosomal recessive Parkinson's during her PhD, and subsequently established her own laboratory studying the effects of alpha-synuclein oligomerisation in neurons. Her work focuses on the interaction between protein aggregation and mitochondrial dysfunction in human neurons.

iv.question: Why is alpha-synuclein oligomerisation toxic?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Sonia has experience in mitochondrial function, proteins aggregation and cell biology

researchInterests.iv: Sonia is working to understand how oligomerisation affects neuronal and astrocytic function, and contributes to Parkinson's pathology.

responsibilities.iv: Sonia will be responsible for prioritising key targets from oligomer mapping, and modelling their function in the human iPSC system. Her laboratory performs directed differentiation of human iPSCs to generate enriched cultures different cell types, and applies single molecule and super resolution imaging approaches to assess oligomer formation, and live cell imaging approaches resolve cellular physiology and mitochondrial function.

biography.iv: Yuko is a postdoctoral research assistant in Dario's research group which locates at University of Dundee. She has a strong background in top-down and bottom-up proteomics studies using mass spectromety. She studied the aggregation and inhibition pathways of amyloid proteins using mass spectrometry and compared the pathways between wild-type and aged amyloid protein during her PhD degree in University of Warwick.

responsibilities.iv: Yuko will be participate in a fundamental research to understand the molecular basis of Parkinson's disease. Her work will focus on understanding the regulation and funciton of two protein kinases implicated in Parkinson's namely LRRK2 and PINK1 and how these enzymes refulate lysosome and mitochondrial dysfunction.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Yuko has years of experience in protein interaction, top-down and bottom-up proteomics, as well as mass spectrometry.

researchInterests.iv: Yuko is interested in studying protein interaction and function using mass spectrometry.

biography.iv: Helen completed her PhD with Paul Greengard at The Rockefeller University where she generated genetic mouse models to study dopamine signaling and striatal-dependent behaviors. From there she joined Bernardo Sabatini’s lab as a post-doc at Harvard Medical School where she elucidated how mutations associated with neurodevelopmental disorders affect synaptic function and network activity. In 2013, Dr. Bateup started her lab at UC Berkeley in the Department of Molecular and Cell Biology. The goal of her research is to understand the cellular and molecular basis of neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders. Her work is defining how disease-associated genetic insults affect gene expression, signaling pathways, synaptic communication, and ultimately behavior.

iv.question: Why are dopamine neurons so sensitive to PD-related genetic insults? What other cell types are involved in PD pathophysiology?
How do different genetic and environmental risk factors for PD converge at the cellular level to produce a common pathology?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Helen has experience working with genetic mouse and human brain organoid models of neurological disease. She is experienced in analyzing signal transduction, gene expression, cellular morphology, electrophysiological properties and synaptic function.

researchInterests.iv: Helen is interested in how mutations associated with neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders alter neuronal function, synaptic communication and plasticity.

responsibilities.iv: Helen will lead the team responsible for the generation of the Cre-dependent SNCA A53T overexpression mice. She will oversee the CRISPRi/a experiments in mouse models that will test the functional consequences of manipulating potential Parkinson's risk genes. The team will investigate how PD risk genes, either alone or in combination with other genetic risk factors, affect cellular function and cell type-specific gene expression in vivo.

jobTitle.iv: Associate Professor of Neurology and Neuroscience; Deputy Chair of Neuroscience

biography.iv: Sreeganga Chandra is an Associate Professor in the Departments of Neurology and Neuroscience, Yale University. She is also the Deputy Chair for the Department of Neuroscience. Dr. Chandra did her postdoctoral training with Dr. Edward Koo at UC San Diego and Thomas Südhof at University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center. The Chandra laboratory explores two inter-related themes –synapse maintenance and neurodegeneration. In particular, the lab investigates Parkinson’s disease genes and risk alleles that encode synaptic proteins and how they impact synaptic structure, function and neuronal health.

iv.question: What is the cell biological basis of trans-synaptic spread of alpha-synuclein?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Sreeganga has worked extensively on alpha-synuclein function, synaptic vesicle cycling, and presynaptic proteostasis.

researchInterests.iv: Sreeganga is working to understand synaptic deficits that occur in neurodegenerative diseases by characterizing familial disease linked genes that encode synaptic proteins, such as alpha-synuclein.

responsibilities.iv: Sreeganga will work with other team members to characterize alpha-synuclein pathology and motor phenotypes in gnotobiotic mice transplanted with control and patient microbiomes. Sreeganga will also spearhead snRNAseq analysis of control and Parkinson's disease brains.

biography.iv: Noah W. Palm, Ph.D., is an Assistant Professor of Immunobiology at the Yale University School of Medicine, where his lab focuses on understanding how the trillions of microbes that live in and on us (our microbiota) interact with and influence their mammalian hosts. His work particularly emphasizes the development of new technologies to deconvolute complex host-microbiota interactions and reveal causal roles for the microbiota in human health and disease. Dr. Palm performed doctoral work with Dr. Ruslan Medzhitov and postdoctoral work with Dr. Richard Flavell, both at Yale University. He is the recipient of multiple honors and awards, including the Smith Family Foundation Award for Excellence in Biomedical Research, Pew Biomedical Scholar Award, and NIH Director's New Innovator Award.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Noah has expertise in immunology, immune-microbiota interactions, human microbiome analyses, the microbiota metabolome, and ultrahigh-throughput functional characterization of host-microbiota interactions.

researchInterests.iv: Noah is interested in understanding the molecular mechanisms through which the microbiome interacts with and influences its mammalian hosts in health and disease.

responsibilities.iv: Noah will be responsible for exploring the potential role of the microbiome in Parkinson's disease using gnotobiotic mouse models and identifying the key mediators of these effects using novel ultrahigh-throughput technologies to profile molecular-level host-microbiota interactions.

biography.iv: Don was an undergraduate in Chemistry at the University of Colorado, Boulder, where he worked with Tom Cech mapping Tetrahymena ribosomal RNA transcripts using R-loop electron microscope imaging of RNA-DNA hybrids.  He completed his Ph.D. in biochemistry with Robert Tjian at the University of California, Berkeley, where he studied the regulation of simian virus 40 (SV40) transcription in vitro and in vivo.  He did postdoctoral work with Gerald Rubin in the University of California, Berkeley Dept. of Biochemistry, where he worked on P transposable elements, characterizing the P element transposase and repressor proteins and the germline-specific splicing of the P element transposase pre-mRNA.  From there he joined the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research and the Dept. of Biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) as an Assistant Professor.  After 5 years, he moved to the Department of Molecular and Cell Biology at the University of California, Berkeley as a tenured Professor, where he has remained.  His group studies P transposable elements in Drosophila and the evolutionarily related vertebrate THAP9 homologs, DNA repair pathways that affect P element transposition and RNA binding proteins that control alternative pre-mRNA splicing in Drosophila and humans.  The lab uses a combination of biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics and genomics to study the mechanisms by which these DNA (transposition) and RNA processing (pre-mRNA splicing) reactions occur.

iv.title: Mechanism and regulation of P element transposition

researchInterests.iv: Don is generally interested in how mutations in RNA binding protein cause defects in RNA processing, including pre-mRNA splicing, and how these alterations to neuronal pathways and gene expression lead to neurodegenerative disorders, specifically Parkinson’s disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD).

responsibilities.iv: Don will lead the coordination of each team, along with our project manager, to oversee the progress and integration of the work being carried out by each group.  Don’s lab will be responsible for generating bulk RNA-seq data from 2D and 3D genome-edited hPSC-generated organoids carrying high-confidence mutations associated with Parkinson’s disease (PD).  His group will analyze gene expression patterns and use their Junction Usage Model (JUM) software to analyze changes in pre-mRNA splicing and polyadenylation in the mutant versus isogenic wild type cells.  These datasets will serve as baseline measurements of gene expression and RNA processing changes that will be used to compare with single-cell RNA-seq and perturb-seq data generated in the Hockemeyer, Soldner and Gilbert labs.

biography.iv:
Roger Barker is the Professor of Clinical Neuroscience at the University of Cambridge and Consultant Neurologist at the Addenbrooke’s Hospital Cambridge. He is a PI in the MRC-Wellcome Trust Stem Cell Institute in Cambridge and Director of the MRC funded UKRMP Stem and Engineered cell hub. 
His research seeks to better define the clinical heterogeneity of Parkinson’s (PD) and Huntington’s disease (HD). This has helped him define the best way by which to take new therapies into the clinic. In this respect he has been heavily involved in gene and cell based trials for patients with these conditions.
