institution.iv: Florey Institute of Neuroscience & Mental Health, The University of Melbourne

biography.iv: Associate Professor Lachlan Thompson is a neurobiologist specialising in neural transplantation. He undertook his training in this area at Lund University, Sweden, where he specialised in transplantation of dopamine neurons in animal models of Parkinson’s disease, including some of the first studies to utilise transgenic cell lines expressing fluorescent proteins in order to study the integration of implanted cells. Now based at the Florey Institute of Neuroscience and Mental Health in Melbourne, his group continues to work in the area of neural transplantation, both as a therapeutic approach for brain and spinal cord repair, but also as a way to understand the properties of neurons generated from human stem cells.

He will also play a role in histological characterisation of the implanted cells to study how each genotype manifests as a pathological phenotype in vivo.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Dave characterizes the properties of basal ganglia and dopaminergic synapses, including the first measurements of quantal release from synapses and (with Dalibor Sames) the first optical techniques to measure neurotransmission. He has  worked for years on the steps implicated in PD pathogenesis.

researchInterests.iv: Dave is interested in normal and diseased synapses, including   interactions between the cortex, striatum, thalamus and dopamine systems that converge to enable learning and motor function.

responsibilities.iv: Dave is responsible (with Dritan and Peter and based on work from Cecilia and Alex) for establishing an improved animal model of PD based on the interactions of the immune system with autoantigens and determining the cell biology of the changes leading to PD pathogenesis.

biography.iv: Cecilia is a Research Assistant Professor in the Center for Infectious Disease, La Jolla Institute for Immunology (LJI), US. She studied inflammasome activation by bacterial products as a graduate student with Thomas Evans at the University of Glasgow, Scotland. Cecilia obtained post-doctoral training at LJI under Dr. Alessandro Sette to understand the role of T cells in the context of tuberculosis infection. She has since dedicated her research to the identification of T cell epitopes and the characterization of T cell subsets. Among her awards is the Tullie and Rickey Families SPARK award (LJI) and the Collaboration for TB Vaccine Discovery Early Career Scientist award from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

researchInterests.iv: Cecilia is interested in understanding T cell-mediated immune responses to various antigens.

responsibilities.iv: Cecilia will lead the project on how antigen-specific T cell reactivity changes with Parkinson’s disease progression and on the identification of neural-derived T cell antigens. Her team’s current work is focused on understanding the role of T cells in neurodegenerative diseases and infectious diseases. Cecilia’s team will tackle this problem from many angles and uses cytokine-detection (e.g., Fluorospot and flow cytometric assays), TCR-repertoire analysis, and RNA-seq among other assays.

biography.iv: Elizabeth completed her PhD in Biophysics at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign as a Fulbright Fellow. She was a Marie Curie Postdoctoral Fellow in the Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry in Munich. She joined the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department faculty at UC San Diego in July 2014. In 2016, she was awarded an NIH Director’s New Innovator Award. She joined the Division of Biological Sciences faculty at UC San Diego in March 2017.

His research concerns the molecular origins of protein misfolding diseases and the development of diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for these diseases.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Gurvir has years of experience in hiPSC culture and directed differentiation to midbrain dopaminergic neurons. He also has vast experience in live-cell imaging, and super-resolution microscopy.

researchInterests.iv: Gurvir works on using hiPSC-derived midbrain dopaminergic neurons as a model for Parkinson's Disease. He recently developed a new protocol to yield highly enriched dopaminergic neurons from hiPSCs.

responsibilities.iv: Gurvir will focus on using hiPSC-derived midbrain dopaminergic neurons to look the pathology of synucleinopathies using a range of patient lines harbouring mutations in the alpha-synuclein gene SNCA. The team aim to understand how mutations in SNCA cause disease with a focus on live single-cell imaging, and super-resolution imaging techniques to study alpha-synuclein aggregation.

biography.iv: Joseph is the Director of the Garvan-Weizmann Centre for Cellular Genomics and Deputy Director of the UNSW Cellular Genomics Futures Institute at the University of New South Wales in Sydney. He currently holds a National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Leadership Investigator Fellowship. He was awarded an NHMRC Research Excellence Award in 2016 and the 2017 Commonwealth Health Minister’s Medal for Excellence in Medical Research. His research is focused on understanding the functional mechanisms by which genetic variants contribute to disease susceptibility at a cellular level, and ultimately achieve therapeutic and diagnostic outcomes.

biography.iv: Ellen is the Branch Chief of the Medical Genetics Branch and is a pediatrician and geneticist in the National Human Genome Research Institute at the NIH. She received her M.D. from Tulane University, and trained in pediatrics at Northwestern and in Clinical Genetics at the NIH. Dr. Sidransky has been a tenured NIH investigator and Section Chief since 2000. Her research interests include both clinical and basic aspects of Gaucher disease and Parkinson disease, studies of genotype/phenotype correlation and genetic modifiers, insights from mouse models, and novel treatment strategies. She played a lead role in establishing the association between glucocerebrosidase and parkinsonism. She received the Van Andel Award for PD Research and  the RO Brady award for Innovation an Accomplishment.

biography.iv: Ashley S. Harms, PhD, is an assistant professor at the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) in the Department of Neurology and the Center for Neurodegeneration and Experimental Therapeutics. As a dedicated neuroimmunologist, Dr. Harms studies the cellular and immunological mechanisms underlying the initiation and progression of alpha-synucleinopathy disorders, with emphasis on antigen presentation. Utilizing novel genetic and viral model approaches to study the role of immune cell subsets, her lab focuses on how the protein alpha-synuclein contributes to microglial activation, peripheral immune cell infiltration, and subsequent activation of the immune response in Parkinson’s disease and multiple system atrophy.

biography.iv: Ulrich Hartl is a director at Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry and a Professor at Munich University. His research focuses on the role of molecular chaperones in protein folding and the mechanisms of diseases associated with protein aggregation. Among his awards are the Lasker Award and the Breakthrough Prize, which he shared with Arthur Horwich.

biography.iv: Marine has been a Research Associate and a PhD student in PI-Dr. François Foulquier's laboratory during the last four years. She studied N-linked glycosylation and the regulation of cellular manganese homeostasis in the specific context of congenital disorders of glycosylation (CDG) associated to a deficiency in TMEM165 gene (TMEM165-CDG). Her work demonstrated that Golgi N-linked glycosylation was tightly regulated and dependent on Golgi manganese homeostasis and may required the activity of the P2A-type ATPase SERCA2. Additionally, she higligthed a functional link between TMEM165 and another P2-type ATPase, SPCA1, in the Golgi compartment.  Within the ASAP consortium, Marine will held a Post-Doc position in the Laboratory of Cellular Transport Systems, headed by Pr. Peter Vangheluwe.

biography.iv: Sarkis Mazmanian, Ph.D. is the Luis & Nelly Soux Professor of Microbiology in the Division of Biology & Biological Engineering at Caltech, in Pasadena CA. His laboratory pioneered the concept that studying the gut microbiome may lead to novel concepts in drug development for certain immunologic and neurological diseases, work that has resulted in several ongoing clinical trials. Dr. Mazmanian has enjoyed numerous honors including the MacArthur Foundation “Genius” award. Most importantly, He has trained many students and fellows who have gone on to successful independent careers in science, medicine and industry.

jobTitle.iv: Professor of Neurology and Center Director

biography.iv: Clemens Scherzer, M.D. is Professor of Neurology at Harvard Medical School. He directs the Center for Advanced Parkinson Research and the Precision Neurology Program of Brigham & Women’s Hospital. Scherzer uses genomes and computation to develop a future, predictive and proactive health care for Parkinson’s and other common neurologic diseases. His is to match precision drugs and biomarkers to the genetic blueprint of individual patients and prevent disease from ever progressing. Scherzer co-founded the major biobanks for Parkinson’s disease, including the Harvard Biomarkers Study. He serves on the Scientific Advisory Board of the American Parkinson Disease Foundation and his work was featured in Science, Scientific American, Washington Post, US News & World Reports, and NOVA Next.

responsibilities.iv: Michael's expertise in mitochondrial biology and knowledge of PINK1/Parkin mitophagy will be used to investigate the mechanisms of autophagosome formation around damaged mitochondria. His team's current work utilises cultured cell models and multiple image modalities (e.g. 3D electron microscopy, light microscopy) combined with gene editing, to understand how autophagosomes form from early phagophore precursors that expand around mitochondria to form a fully sealed autophagosome.

jobTitle.iv: Associate Professor and Honorary Consultant Neurologist

biography.iv: Christos Proukakis is a practicing clinical academic neurologist, currently an Associate Professor in the University College London Institute of Neurology, and Honorary Consultant Neurologist. His clinical and research focus is Parkinson’s disease / synucleinopathies. He hypothesized and is investigating the role of somatic mutations in the brain in these. His lab demonstrated somatic copy number gains (CNVs) in the alpha-synuclein gene, and produced the first genome-wide somatic CNV calls in synucleinopathy brain using single cell whole genome sequencing in MSA. He is also using other novel genetic analysis technologies, such as long-read sequencing for the difficult GBA gene.

biography.iv: Luke Gilbert is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Urology, Cellular and Molecular Pharmacology, the Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center and the Innovative Genomics Institute at UCSF. He was an early pioneer in repurposed CRISPR systems that are used to turn genes on (CRISPRa) and off (CRISPRi) by editing the epigenome. His lab uses innovative new CRISPR technologies to systematically edit the epigenome and transcriptome. He continues to pioneer new CRISPR functional genomics platforms for genome scale screens and genetic interaction mapping applied to high impact problems in biology.

biography.iv: Dirk's work focuses on to establishing reliable techniques that allow modeling of human diseases using genetically engineered human and stem cell and mouse models. As a principle investigator at the University of California Berkeley his team is leveraging their expertise in stem cell biology, mouse genetics and genome editing to elucidate the mechanism stem cell immortality and defects in tissue regeneration. His research team seeks to understand the consequences adult stem depletion syndrome and how this impacts tumor formation, stem cell renewal as well as cellular and organismal aging. We address these questions using genetically engineered human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs), as well as human adult stem cells, human organoid systems and genetic mouse models.

biography.iv: Kristen is working with ASAP to launch the funding initiative and develop the ASAP Hub collaboration platform. Kristen founded Strategies for Open Science (Stratos) in 2019 to help synthesize open science efforts into a cohesive movement. Stratos partners with open science funders, advocates, and infrastructure providers to produce tangible results towards open scholarship. Kristen has a 20-year history working to accelerate advances in science and research communication. She co-founded the Collaborative Knowledge Foundation, was the Publisher at the Public Library of Science (PLOS), and held leadership positions at HighWire Press, Atypon, and BIOSIS.  Kristen is on the board of the American Institute of Physics Publishing, Code for Science and Society, Rapid Science, and ASAPbio. She holds advisory board positions with Invest in Open Infrastructure (IOI), MIT Press, Stencila, DataSeer, and PREreview.

biography.iv: Ayse received her PhD in 2010 in Lund (Sweden). There, she gained expertise in developing animal models of neurodegeneration, particularly by designing and applying specific adeno-associated viral vectors in vivo to modulate disease-related gene expression in the dopaminergic system. Later, she worked at the German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases, Bonn (Germany) as a post-doctoral researcher, where she expanded her research to investigate Parkinson’s disease pathology beyond the nigrostriatal system. Particularly, she is interested in elucidating mechanisms of alpha-synuclein spreading throughout the brain as well as in the peripheral nervous system. She is currently pursuing her research interests as a staff scientist at the German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases, Bonn.

biography.iv: Sara is undergoing her PhD research at the UCL Institute of Neurology. She completed her undergraduate degree in Medicine at Autonomous University of Barcelona, Spain, in 2012. Afterwards she received Neurology Speciality training at Vall Hebrón University Hospital, Barcelona, Spain, following the National Spanish Speciality Program. Currently, she is a member of Professor Schapira’s laboratory. Her ongoing research focuses on the immune determinants of GBA-related Parkinson’s disease.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Sara is a clinical neurologist who has worked in a Movement Disorders clinic and has experience working with patient-level data and biological samples.

researchInterests.iv: Sara is interested in the role of neuroinflammation in the pathogenesis of Parkinson disease, especially how inflammatory processes influence the risk of GBA mutations carriers to develop PD.

responsibilities.iv: Sara will be in charge of processing different types of bio samples from cohorts of GBA mutation carriers. The samples will be used cohorts in order to create and validate special lab models of the disease to identify how different types of immune cells within the central nervous system interact with other cell types and with alpha-synuclein.

biography.iv: Emmanuelle LE CHATELIER is a Senior Research Scientist at MetaGenoPolis INRAE. She has an Engineering degree and a PhD in Microbiology, with a long experience in molecular biology in the field of DNA replication. Since 2010, she gained an expertise in computational biology and became Data Analyst and Investigator in metagenomics.

researchInterests.iv: Emmanuelle is interested in human and animal metagenomics.

responsibilities.iv: Emmanuelle gained an expertise in computational biology and more specifically the analysis of gut and oral microbial ecosystems through metagenomics data-mining, genome reconstruction and association with host phenotypes. Her team's current research aims to decipher the role of microbes in human health and disease, and identify new diagnostic/prognostic biomarkers of disease.

biography.iv: Todd is the CEO of the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.  He holds a PhD in Neuroscience from the University of Virginia.  As a postdoctoral fellow with Tim Greenamyre at Emory University, Todd developed models of Parkinson's disease focused on the role of environmental factors as triggers for neurodegeneration.  Following his postdoc, Todd joined the MJFF as a staff scientist prior to leading the Foundation's programmatic strategy.  He has been CEO since 2011.

His team is focusing on various types  of "Selective-Autophagy" in cells, wherein cargo such as dysfunctional mitochondria, invading pathogens or even lysosomes themselves are specifically demarcated for destruction via the autophagy pathway, and how these processes go awry in various neurological disorders.

biography.iv: Jim is Professor of Pathology and Cell Biology at Columbia University.  He is both a clinical neuropathologist and research neuroscientist, who has investigated the development, function, and pathology of glial cells in the mammalian central nervous system.  He was the Director of Neuropathology at Columbia for 25 years.  He has served on many review panels and editorial boards and has received continuous funding from the NIH, including a Javits Award, and foundations for many years.

biography.iv: Enza Maria is Professor of Medical Genetics at the University of Pavia and head of the Neurogenetics Research Centre at the IRCCS Mondino Foundation in Pavia. She is a neurogeneticist with a long-standing expertise in monogenic PD. She identified mutations in the PINK1 gene as causative of autosomal recessive PD, and has largely contributed to characterizing its neuroprotective functions. Enza Maria is currently a member of the Scientific Committee and Monogenic Hub Team of the ASAP GP2 initiative.

biography.iv: Vidyadhara D J is a postdoc and U.S. DoD Early Investigator in the Depts. of Neurology & Neuroscience, Yale. He holds a PhD in Neurophysiology from National Institute of Mental Health & Neurosciences, India, along with a Master’s in Medical Physiology. He started his research career studying ischemic brain injury as well as teaching Human Physiology. He shifted to PD research during his doctoral studies. He worked on characterizing age-related glial changes in the human nigra, the mechanisms for mice strain-dependent differential susceptibility to parkinsonian toxin MPTP, and autophagy as a therapeutic target for PD. Currently, he is investigating the role of endolysosomal system in pathogenesis of PD. His studies focus on elucidating the mechanisms for auxilin and GBA1 mediated PD.

biography.iv: Alan Landay PhD is Professor in the Departments of Internal Medicine and Microbial Pathogens and Immunity and is Vice Chair for Research in the Department of Internal Medicine at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago.  He has been involved in HIV research for over 40 years. He has participated on the Office of AIDS Research HIV and Aging Committee and has been an advisor to UN AIDS on HIV and Aging. Over the past 10 years, his research focus has been on studies of the human microbiome and metabolome.ACTG Lab group. Dr. Landay has published over 490 peer reviewed papers focused on basic and clinical studies of HIV with an emphasis on the role of immune activation, inflammation and microbiome in HIV pathogenesis and therapy.

biography.iv: Patrick has been investigating the causes of neurodegeneration for two decades, working on Alzheimer’s disease, the Prion diseases and, since 2005, Parkinson’s disease. He studied biochemistry at the University of Manchester and then undertook graduate studies at the MRC Prion Unit before moving to the National Institute on Aging in Bethesda were he started working on the cell biology of Parkinson's disease. Patrick returned to the UK in 2007 to take up a Brain Research Trust fellowship at the UCL Institute of Neurology. From 2010 to 2015 he was a Parkinson’s UK research fellow, investigating mutations in the LRRK2 gene, starting his own group at the University of Reading in 2013 as an Associate Professor. Patrick moved to the Royal Veterinary College, University of London, in 2020.

biography.iv: Hervé obtained a PhD in Tumor Immunology from the University of Nantes (France), and spent 2 years at Wistar Institute (Philadelphia, PA). Recruited as PI at Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique (INRA, now INRAE) in Nantes. He moved to Paris as Research Director in 2002 to develop research on human gut microbiota. Hervé presently heads a research laboratory at INRAE and is one of the Scientific Directors at MetaGenoPolis. His goal is to provide a better understanding of the symbiosis between gut microbiota and its host in health and diseases and to decipher the molecular mechanisms of interaction between intestinal bacteria and human cells. Finding these molecular mediators will provide target for manipulation or therapeutics tools to restore symbiosis in chronic diseases.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Sonya has research experience in Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and epilepsy.

biography.iv:
Sonya is the Deputy Director of Aligning Science Across Parkinson’s.

Previously, Sonya was the Vice President of Research and Innovation at the Epilepsy Foundation. While there, she oversaw the growth of the Epilepsy Therapy Project, an entrepreneurship incubator providing seed funding and mentorship to epilepsy startups, launched the Epilepsy Innovation Institute, an innovation incubator tackling high risk projects in the epilepsy space, and supported early career research development through the Next Generation Programs. Sonya has been with the Epilepsy Foundation since 2016. Prior to joining the Epilepsy Foundation, she worked at the Milken Institute Center for Strategic Philanthropy, tasked with identifying key philanthropic opportunities poised to have a transformative impact on the state of research and developing research programs.

Sonya completed her postdoctoral training at both the Johns Hopkins University and the Max-Delbrück Center in Berlin, Germany. She earned her PhD in neuroscience from Georgetown University. She has authored numerous scientific articles and received a number of honors, including an Alexander von Humboldt Postdoctoral Research Fellowship, a National Science Foundation fellowship, a national research service award from the National Institutes of Health, the Harold N Glassman Award for best science dissertation at Georgetown University, and the Mark A. Smith prize from the Journal of Neurochemistry. Sonya has demonstrated a strong commitment to science outreach, developing several educational initiatives such as the Georgetown Medical Center Graduate Student Research Grants program and the Epilepsy Foundation / Danny Did startup accelerator course. She also lectures on the Fundamentals of Neuroscience as an adjunct professor at Georgetown University.

biography.iv: Dritan Agalliu is an Associate Professor of Pathology and Cell Biology in Neurology at Columbia University Medical Center. Over the past 10 years, my laboratory has published multiple studies to elucidate the signaling pathways and mechanisms that regulate the blood-brain and blood-retina barrier (BBB/BRB) formation during CNS development and its breakdown in neurological disorders associated with BBB dysfunction such as ischemic stroke or multiple sclerosis (MS). In addition, My laboratory has a long-standing interest in understanding the role of the adaptive immune system (Th17/Th1 lymphocytes) in autoimmune CNS sequelae following recurring S. pyogenes infections, specifically how CD4+ T cell subtypes induce neurovascular damage, neuroinflammation and neuronal circuit dysfunction.

He received several awards for his scientific contributions including the NRC President’s outstanding award, the CSC Maxxam award and the CNPN Tony Pawson award.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Jasmin has advanced expertise in mass-spectrometry based proteomics including crosslinking, data-independent analysis and phosphoproteomics as well as quantitative analysis.

researchInterests.iv: Jasmin's research interest is to investigate the role of LRRK2 in Parkinson's disease as it is the protein most often found mutated in hereditary forms of this disease using mass spectrometry.

responsibilities.iv: Jasmin has expertise in mass spectrometry-based proteomics and will therefore investigate the interactome of the LRRK2 protein. Therefore, Jasmin will investigate how these mutations influence the phosphoproteome in a quantitative way. Further, she will be involved in characterizing different LRRK2 forms by crosslinking mass spectrometry with her colleague Peter.

His work focused on the functional interplay between striatal dopamine and acetylcholine, characterizing the alterations occurring in distinct rodent models of movement disorders and their consequences on striatal synaptic plasticity. biography.iv: Lesley studied Psychology at McGill University before moving on to complete a MSc in Dementia at University College London (UCL). She is currently a research assistant in Professor Huw Morris' group at UCL.

iv.question: How can we use genetics to explain phenotypic and pathologic heterogeneity in Lewy body disorders?
What are the genetic drivers of progression in Lewy body disorders?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Lesley has experience in multidisciplinary research in dementia. She is currently developing an expertise in genetic analyses.

researchInterests.iv: Lesley is interested in the genetic architecture of Lewy body disorders.

responsibilities.iv: Lesley will conduct large scale genetic analyses of Lewy body disorder cases from brain banks,  integrated with neuropathological and clinical data. She hopes this will enable better understanding of genetic drivers of disease and decode the pathological and clinical heterogeneity in Lewy body disorders.

biography.iv: Yunlong is an Assistant scientist in Su-chun Zhang's lab, Waisman center, University of Wisconsin - Madison. He used stem cell models to study the development of nervous system and the mechanisms under neurodegenerative diseases. he is also working to develop cell therapy to cure Parkinson's Disease.

iv.question: What type of cells contribute to the non-motor symptoms in Parkinson's Diseases?
Do hPSC derived dopaminergic neural progenitors provide life long recovery for PD patients?
Do cell therapy work to solve the non-motor symptoms such as sleep disorder, mood disorder and pain in PD patients?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Yunlong has years of experience in iPSC generation, culture and neural differentiation. He has utilized the genome editing tool CRISPR/CAS9 in editing human iPSCs for over 5 years.

researchInterests.iv: Yunlong is interested in studying neural development and mechanism of neurodegenerative diseases using stem cell models. he is also interested in developing therapies for the diseases.

responsibilities.iv: Yunlong will be responsible for establishing the genetically modified cell lines in human pluripotent stem cells to study the genes of interest in the development of Parkinson's disease.

iv.question: To what extent do mitochondrial damage induce pre-autophagosomal structure formation?
Does mutation in autophagy adaptor protein affect the morphology of mitophagosome?

researchInterests.iv: Leo is interested in the molecular mechanism of mitophagy induction and spatiotemporal regulation of mitophagosome formation.

responsibilities.iv: Leo will be responsible for performing live-cell super-resolution imaging to investigate the kinetics of PINK1 accumulation, recruitment kinetics of Parkin, autophagy adaptors and core complexes. Also, he will be involved in studying the engulfment of mitochondria using FIB-SEM/CLEM microscopy.

iv.question: How does lysosome dysfunction contribute to the development and progression of Parkinson’s disease?
How does LRRK2 influence lysosome function?

biography.iv: Aastha completed her doctoral research at IISER, Mohali, India on mechanisms whereby the endo-lysosomal pathway is remodeled by Salmonella.

responsibilities.iv: Aastha will contribute to the development of assays to investigate the recruitment of protein complexes to the surface of lysosomes. She will primarily focus on the role of LRRK2 and its downstream targets in the regulation of lysosome homeostasis.

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Aastha has extensive experience with live cell imaging assays to investigate membrane traffic and lysosome function.

researchInterests.iv: Aastha is interested in mechanisms of lysosome transport, activity and signaling.

biography.iv: Sakthi is currently working as a Post-doctoral research associate in Prof. Su-Chun Zhang's lab at the Waisman Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison. Prior to coming to Madison, Sakthi has spent two years as a post doctoral researcher in Prof. Lynn Raymond's laboratory (UBC, Canada). His research work at UBC was focusing on Huntington's Disease using medium spiny neurons derived from hiPSCs. He has a PhD in Molecular and Cellular Biology. He did his graduate studies on Molecular mechanisms of Nociception under the supervision of Prof. Antonio-Ferrer Montiel, University of Miguel Hernandez, Spain. He was awarded with the Spanish government's international fellowship to support his graduate studies.

iv.question: How mutations decide to target a specific cell type to degenerate?
How far membrane trafficking impairment could contribute to neuronal cell death?

researchInterests.iv: Sakthi is interested in understanding the activity dependent changes in dopaminergic neurons and it's association with aging and PD pathology.

responsibilities.iv: In this PD5D project, Sakthi will provide his expertise on stem cell derived neurons, electrophysiology and aging to perform cell and stage- specific mechanistic analysis on human pluripotent stem cell derived neurons. Sakthi will be responsible for the generation of new stem cell lines (gene editing), neuronal differentiation and perform functional analysis to understand how disease associated variants cause neuronal dysfunction in PD and its specificity to the cell types.

biography.iv: Patricia is a postdoctoral researcher in the Department of Cellular Biochemistry, Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry. She studied genetic and pharmacological therapies for inherited metabolic diseases as a graduate student.

iv.question: How are alpha-synuclein aggregates taken up by cells and how do they template aggregation?
Which factor are involved in the transcellular propagation of alpha-synuclein aggregates?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Patricia has years of experience on in vitro protein aggregation and prion-like seeding and spreading mechanisms in mammalian cells,

researchInterests.iv: Patricia is interested in studying factors involved in alpha-synuclein aggregates seeding and spreading, with special interest on extracellular chaperones.

responsibilities.iv: Patricia will be responsible for setting up different cellular models to study alpha-synuclein prion-like propagation to understand how alpha-synuclein aggregates enter cells, how template further aggregation and which factors are involved in these mechanisms.

biography.iv: Elisa received her MD and residency in neurology from the University-Hospital of Modena and Reggio Emilia in Modena, Italy and she is currently undertaking her PhD at University College London, UK. During her residency, she studied the application of smartphone software for home monitoring of motor symptoms in Parkinson disease patients at University College London. Currently, she is researching the microbiome as potential risk factor of conversion to Parkinson disease in GBA carriers.

iv.question: Are alterations in the microbiome composition cause or consequence of Parkinson disease?
How can microbial ligands and structures be sensed by the intestinal cells and trigger the alpha-synuclein cascade within the gut?

researchInterests.iv: Elisa is interested in the role of the oral and gut microbiome as risk factor of conversion to Parkinson disease in GBA carriers.

responsibilities.iv: Elisa will be responsible for applying whole genome sequencing, HPLC and GC-MS to investigate the genomic and functional composition of the oral and gut microbiome of mice carrying GBA mutation, and GBA human carriers and patients with Parkinson disease. She will also evaluate how different structures expressed by microorganisms (pathogen-associated molecular patterns) can influence the expression of α-synuclein in cultured mouse and human intestinal cells.

biography.iv: Janelle is an Assistant Professor at the University of Montreal (Montreal, Canada) since August 2018. She is combining direct neural reprogramming and induced pluripotent stem cell work to study the pathophysiology of PD, as well as working on developing direct glial reprogramming technologies to provide more complex patient derived cell-based systems with the aim of studying the age-associated pathophysiology of neurodegenerative disorders. She has trained with both Roger A. Barker at the University of Cambridge (Cambridge, UK) and Malin Parmar at Lund University (Lund, Sweden).

iv.question: Can induced neurons serve as a tool to study the heterogeneity of idiopathic PD?
How does age drives the development of PD?
To what extent do glial cells contribute to PD?

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Janelle has expertise in PD patient-derived neural in vitro models

researchInterests.iv: Janelle develops and uses cell reprogramming technologies to generate PD patient-derived neural cells to better understand the role of aging in PD pathogenesis.

responsibilities.iv: Janelle will be in charge of generating different types of brain cells, including dopaminergic neurons, astrocytes and microglia from iPSCs of PD patients carrying different types of mutations. These cells will be co-cultured together to study the role of PD-related proteins in the immune response leading to dopaminergic degeneration in patient-based model systems.

biography.iv: Jorge is a Research advisor in the Department of Pathology and Cell Biology, University of Montreal. He did a PhD at the UdeM, where he studied the role of neuroinflammation in neurodegeneration. He also did a Postdoc at the Neuron-Glia interaction Unit at the NEI/NIH.

iv.question: How peripheral Mitochondrial antigen presentation is involved in PD?
Does MitAP increase promote microglia activation?
How CD8 T cells infiltrate into the CNS?

A magnetic microbead occlusion model to induce ocular hypertension-dependent glaucoma in mice

expertiseAndResourceDescription.iv: Jorge has experience working on neuroinflammation

researchInterests.iv: Jorge is interested in understanding the link between the immune system and PD. Particularly, the mechanisms underlying the role of MitAP on neurotoxicity and neuroinflammation.

responsibilities.iv: Jorge will collaborate in the team by performing the MitAP assay on peripheral immune cells, including macrophages and dendritic cells and cytokines expression as well.  In addition, Jorge have a vast experience working on neurodegeneration and he will collaborate in understanding the role of MitAP in the CNS immune cell (Microglia).

biography.iv: Nouf is a postdoctoral fellow from Professor Monther Abu-Remalieh Lab in the Department of Chemical Engineering at Stanford University. She studied miRNA role in viral infection as a PhD student with Dr.  Amy Buch at Edinburgh University. Her current work is primarily focusing on the identification of age-related changes in metabolic profile of mice and elucidation of the signaling mechanism underlying these metabolic changes. She is also studying neurodegenerative disease ‘Batten disease’, a lysosomal storage disorder (LSD) caused by a mutation in lysosomal membrane protein, named CLN3. Her current effort is to determine the unknown biochemical function of CLN3 and how its mutation disrupts the metabolic homeostasis of lysosomes.

iv.question: How does lysosomal dysfunctions contribute to Parkinson’s disease.
What is the role of metabolic crosstalk in Parkinson’s disease and other forms of neurodegeneration, such as lysosomal storage disease?

researchInterests.iv: I am interested in the role of lysosome in health and diseases

responsibilities.iv: can be responsible for purifying lysosomes from cells or mice tissues (disease model) to study their contents (proteins, metabolites, and lipids)
